<p><strong>US government agencies</strong> are entering a period of gradual recovery following the hectic months since the first US case of COVID-19 was confirmed in January. Resuming a semblance of normal operations for 2.1 million nonpostal workers and 1.4 million active-duty military will be an undertaking that lasts many months and spans multiple stages.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1fa8ccb7-1f72-4f18-9bee-79566a487228"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1fa8ccb7-1f72-4f18-9bee-79566a487228" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Strengthening the federal workforce, <em>Analytical perspectives: FY 2020</em>, Office of Management and Budget, March 2019, whitehouse.gov.</span></span></span></a></span> Agencies will have to carefully plan whether, how, and when to return fully to workand provide answers for each state and city in which their employees work. They will have to prioritize and sequence agency services and functions and work to create appropriate infrastructure and safeguards for employees and the citizens they serve. Federal agency leaders also face strained budgets and a substantial work backlog as well as continuing responsibility to help manage the profound humanitarian toll that COVID-19 has taken.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>These are significant burdens by any measure, but the pandemic crisis also offers federal agencies the opportunity to reimagine an operational next normal. Like the private sector, agencies could question long-held assumptions and operate in previously unimaginable ways. As they plan a return, agency leaders should take stock of lessons already learned while the opportunity to effect change is greatest.</p>
<p>Agencies tackling the challenge of reopening should therefore consider focusing on two areas: returning employees to work and reimagining a next normal for government operations.</p>
<h2>A blueprint for returning employees to work</h2>
<p>To tackle the challenge of returning employees to work, agencies can consider three main activities: segmenting agencies, assessing infrastructure, and planning the return.</p>
<h3>Segmenting and prioritizing agency services and employees</h3>
<p>Agency leaders will have to make some hard choices as reopening goes forward. Two key activities will be sequencing the reopening of operations and segmenting their workforces. </p>
<p>Agencies can segment the reopening of operations based on criticality and risk, assessing first the urgency to reopen the service and then how effectively a service can occur without compromising employee and public health (Exhibit 1). This estimationincluding considering both the intrinsic public health risk of an activity, as well as its potential to be modified with safeguardswill allow agencies to sequence its services into four categories:</p>
<p><em><strong>1. Essential low-contact services.</strong></em> Because these operations are both low risk for viral transmission and high valuefor instance, some national security and law enforcement activitiesthey should be at the head of the queue for reopening. Agencies can think through the necessary actions to get these vital services up and running as quickly as possible, prioritizing those that have been most affected during the period of remote operations.</p>
<p><em><strong>2. Essential high-contact services.</strong></em> Agencies will need to think through additional safeguards necessary to reopen and restore services quickly while minimizing the health risk to workers and the public. For example, inspections that protect the health and welfare of US residents traditionally require site visits. Actions could include steps to reduce or defer demand for these difficult-to-deliver services.</p>
<p><em><strong>3. Flexible low-contact services.</strong></em> In many cases, the task will be to develop processes and tools to sustain long-term remote operations. For instance, passport services may have a low urgency to reopen in-person citizen services and will have to ponder managing internal operations remotely. Agencies should consider whether any services or workers can be transitioned to remote work permanently.</p>
<p><em><strong>4. Deferrable high-contact services.</strong></em> The questions to consider here are whether these services can be deferred or reduced while viral transmission is active or whether the mode of service delivery can be reconfigured to reduce risk while still maintaining adequate service levels. This may include policy development, traditionally done in offices, that may move to sustained remote work.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/covid%2019%20reopening%20federal%20agency%20operations%20and%20reimagining%20a%20next%20normal/svgz_mck_pssp_covid%20federal%20reopening_ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Agencies can sequence the reopening of government operations based on criticality and risk." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/covid%2019%20reopening%20federal%20agency%20operations%20and%20reimagining%20a%20next%20normal/svgz_mck_pssp_covid%20federal%20reopening_ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>To deliver these services, agencies can categorize jobs or functions by which specific roles and teams are truly essential for delivering a service, regardless of where they sit in the hierarchy. Then, agencies can map a sequence of which jobs to bring back and when to specific locations (in accordance with state and local governments reopening laws), enabling managers to individualize work plans. In doing so, agencies can consider three workforce categories for the post-shelter-at-home environment: </p>
<ul>
    <li><em>On-site critical workers,</em> whose presence on-site is essential to perform their jobs. They can be recalled in stages based on local health conditions, but a detailed plan should look at virus spread, guidance from local public health authorities, workforce readiness for return to work, and legal liability. </li>
    <li><em>On-site flexible workers,</em> many of whom might be able to complete their jobs with additional technology or simple interventions, such as being allowed to return to the office to collect documents and files. Ramp-up might be slower for these workers and include staggered shifts and flexible work arrangements as well as retraining to build more flexible skill sets.</li>
    <li><em>Virtual workers, </em> who can continue to carry out their roles effectively while working from home. Remote work may also be the best choice for employees who are in specialized roles or are single points of failure for operational continuitythat is, for whom the risk of falling ill traveling to or working in an office is simply too large for the agencys mission. In all cases, agencies should focus on providing any additional support necessary to ensure productivity, connectivity, and health. </li>
</ul>
<p>Across these worker types, agencies should consider new demands and opportunities, identifying where reskilling and hiring is needed to fill new roles and responsibilities quickly.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>Importantly, agency employees may not be able or willing to return to work. Many workers care for young children, parents, or other loved ones affected by the pandemic. Without support, such as reopening of schools or childcare services, workers may need to continue to work remotely or not at all. Furthermore, some employees may themselves be members of vulnerable populations. </p>
<p>To inform their plans, agencies can start by surveying employees readiness and comfort in returning on-site. They can also temporarily redeploy employees in lower-priority jobs or functions to higher-priority areas to fill critical gaps. </p>
<h3>Assessing infrastructure and enacting safeguards</h3>
<p>Measures to protect on-site workers will vary by workplace and type of work. Office workers, for example, will need much different methods than those required for transportation, security, or administration agents. To provide appropriate infrastructure across the agency, leaders must be able to accurately predict the working conditions for each roleparticularly the level of contact with members of the public or other federal workers or contractors and of control over work environment (Exhibit 2). </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/covid%2019%20reopening%20federal%20agency%20operations%20and%20reimagining%20a%20next%20normal/svgz_mck_pssp_covid%20federal%20reopening_ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Measures to safeguard site-critical workers will vary by workplace and type of work." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/covid%2019%20reopening%20federal%20agency%20operations%20and%20reimagining%20a%20next%20normal/svgz_mck_pssp_covid%20federal%20reopening_ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Measures can be developed to meet the specific needs of each worker archetype and should cover three types of health-centered interventions:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Measures to ensure healthy humans, such as enforcing physical distancing and adequately sanitizing materials and products that come into contact with the broader population</li>
    <li>Healthy business operations, including policies aimed at keeping workers safe, such as monitoring workers temperatures, embracing work-from-home policies, and instituting flexible sick leave</li>
    <li>Practices to limit physical contact and create a healthy work environment, such as installation of barriers between workers, adequate ventilation, no-touch bathrooms, adequate supplies of hand sanitizer, and both routine and targeted cleaning and sanitizing</li>
</ul>
<p>Most employers have already made progress toward this planning. In a recent survey of US employers, a majority said they planned to physically separate desks or use barriers in their work environments and to close common areas and remove communal food and beverage serving equipment. Seventy-seven percent also planned to implement temperature checks for employees58 percent of whom said they planned to make this check mandatory for all employeesand 55 percent planned to implement contact tracing.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9d378d09-9819-47b9-9328-3a634104cce0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9d378d09-9819-47b9-9328-3a634104cce0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey survey of US employers (n = 100), conducted May 7, 2020 to May 13, 2020; the survey asked company leaders about practices their companies have implemented or are planning to implement to keep employees safe as part of reopening and return-to-work protocols for COVID-19.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b4afbb9f1-a9cf-49c5-a44e-abdeea4e8255%7d%40en">Public Sector Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Visit our Economic Development page</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>Yet enacting adequate safeguards is not as simple as identifying and implementing the correct interventions. Agencies should examine how to get workers back to work safely while ensuring a great employee experience and a sustainable, long-term infrastructure. To tackle this challenge, agencies can focus on laying the groundwork for successful implementation and encouraging adoption among employees. </p>
<h3>Planning and executing the return</h3>
<p>Planning a safe and effective return will require coordination across an individual agency, as well as with local, state, and other parts of the federal government. In fact, 11 of the 18 cabinet-level federal agencies have employees in all 50 stateswith approximately 93 percent of the total US federal workforce living outside Washington, DC. Indeed, there are federal employees and facilities in almost every county in the country.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7b9a477f-1b7d-49d4-8af6-56e112c9f9c4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7b9a477f-1b7d-49d4-8af6-56e112c9f9c4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Federal Workforce Data, Office of Personnel Management, updated June 2019, fedscope.opm.gov; FY 2018 Federal Real Property Profile Data for Civilian Agencies, General Services Administration, updated May 28, 2020, gsa.gov.</span></span></span></a></span> <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/using-a-crisis-nerve-center-to-help-reopen-the-economy">A cross-agency governance structure</a> that tackles this complexity (and other major focus areas of reopening) will be key to successfully managing this process (Exhibit 3).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/covid%2019%20reopening%20federal%20agency%20operations%20and%20reimagining%20a%20next%20normal/svgz_mck_pssp_covid%20federal%20reopening_ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The integrated COVID-19 nerve center is based on five cross-functional teams." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/covid%2019%20reopening%20federal%20agency%20operations%20and%20reimagining%20a%20next%20normal/svgz_mck_pssp_covid%20federal%20reopening_ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Agencies will also have to take stock of work backlogs. Major projects will have been paused or slowed by the virus, and agencies should ascertain where to focus their resources and how to reprioritize. Agencies can conduct a rapid portfolio review and choose which activities or resources to continue, stop, defer, or ramp downand implement these decisions immediately. </p>
<p>Effective communication will be key to executing a safe return to an environment that encourages adoption of safeguards and is conducive to reimagination. Employees will look to their leaders for guidance, care, and empathy. In turn, leadership should consider the following guidelines when communicating:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Be visible and communicate transparently</li>
    <li>Keep calm and set a tone of <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/how-to-demonstrate-calm-and-optimism-in-a-crisis">bounded optimism</a></li>
    <li>Focus on public health, emphasizing facts and reality</li>
    <li>Be clear about whats expected of employees to ensure their safety</li>
    <li>Acknowledge emotions and uncertainty</li>
    <li>Keep messages short and simple</li>
    <li>Anticipate and solicit questions, and provide honest responses</li>
</ul>
<p>In the same survey of US employers mentioned above, 83 percent of employers said they have implemented new communication channels or messages to encourage safe return, and an equal share are planning to offer return-to-work trainings.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5c5d5564-ba74-42e5-9d52-1ea4255a5fb0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5c5d5564-ba74-42e5-9d52-1ea4255a5fb0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey survey of US employers (n = 100), conducted May 7, 2020 to May 13, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>An engaging communication strategy will help agency leadership account for employees experiences as they plan for reopening, keep employees informed as reopening plans evolve across geographies, and improve employees comfort to return to on-site work. </p>
<h2>Reimagining the next normal of federal agency operations </h2>
<p>Even as agencies plan a safe and effective return to work, they should not wait to take advantage of the opportunities revealed by the crisis to institute the next normal. At both an organizational and individual level, the culture and environment are ripe for once-in-a-generation positive change. And done right, this change can lead to better services for citizens, better experience for government employees, and an overall accelerated step-change in how the government serves the country.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Restarting national economies during coronavirus, part two" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/restarting%20national%20economies%20during%20coronavirus%20part%20two/restart-national-economies2-980088330-standard-1536x1536.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Restarting national economies during coronavirus, part two</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/restarting-national-economies-during-coronavirus-part-two" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the article</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>Through this crisis, organizations have realized how quickly they can move. The pace and scale of innovation has accelerated: by necessity, organizations have been forced to confront the reality of exactly what can and cannot be accomplished outside traditional processes. Going forward, employees will expect flexible hours and locations, as well as assistance to manage ever-pressing family and health needs, given gaps in elder and childcare services. And many employers are already thinking about the scale of this flexibilityfor example, 44 percent of US employers surveyed believe that at least a quarter of their desk-based employees would be able to work from home permanently in a new normal.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b0bb109f-2364-4cd2-83c9-467a71442c9d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b0bb109f-2364-4cd2-83c9-467a71442c9d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey survey of US employers (n = 100), conducted May 7, 2020 to May 13, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Citizen expectations have changed as well: across demographics, there is likely to be an increased acceptance of and desire for seamless, contactless digital service. Agencies can look to the medical field for proof of changefor example, 97 percent of respondents to a recent survey said they were either somewhat or very likely to use telemedicine for future appointments, even though only 8 percent of respondents had tried telehealth versus a traditional in-person visit.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8e6cc1f1-c933-40ca-afe8-dc55a35d17bf"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8e6cc1f1-c933-40ca-afe8-dc55a35d17bf" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey COVID-19 Consumer Survey, conducted April 13, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Finally, administrative demands will have shifted, with increased expectation of flexibility and cross-functional skills from the workforce, as well as to find new ways to deliver service effectively and efficiently given budget constraints.</p>
<p>As organizations are forced to adapt to the implications of COVID-19, many are finding faster, simpler, and less-expensive ways to operate. These practices should continue after the crisis to direct taxpayer dollars to where they can have the most impact. Organizations have been forced to pare down to essential operations; as a result, there is a unique opportunity to uncover which services are truly necessary in the next normal. Finally, the 2020 fiscal year budget is likely to be more robust than in coming years, and agencies should use this opportunity to set themselves up for leaner years by changing their operations to serve the public better and more cost-effectively.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>As organizations are forced to adapt to the implications of COVID-19, many are finding faster, simpler, and less-expensive ways to operate.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>At the same time, agency leaders are faced with the classic challenge of focusing on the immediate, urgent issues while finding mindshare to focus on these strategic questions. Private-sector organizations also recognize this opportunity and are rethinking everythingfrom technology companies rethinking their real estate portfolio and planning a more decentralized approach to staffing, to financial institutions creating a future of work task force to devote thinking to employees future needsall in an effort to protect against future shocks to the workforce and plan for what is needed to be successful in the next normal. </p>
<p>To successfully reimagine how the government operates, we have identified six approaches that agency leaders could take: </p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Gain support from leadership.</em> First, assign a respected senior leader to sponsor reimagination work and clearly communicate to the workforce that it is a leadership decision and topic.</li>
    <li><em>Dedicate resources.</em> Convene a dedicated and effective reimagine team to work alongside the team coordinating immediate return. The team can include representation from different agency parts or functions.</li>
    <li><em>Apply customer-experience tools to rethink service delivery.</em> Agencies can employ customer-experience tools such as journey mapping to uncover worker and public needs and pain points, which will have changed during the crisis. Using a resident lens, agencies can address safety and resilience and create distinctive long-term solutions while accounting for improved human experience.</li>
    <li><em>Lean on data.</em> Use metrics and data to inform decision making wherever possiblefor example, employee surveys and metrics dashboards to assess new ways of working.</li>
    <li><em>Review mission, strategy, and backlog.</em> Review existing strategy and mission and adjust as needed. Continuously groom and reprioritize project backlogs as reimagine objectives clarify.</li>
    <li><em>Review and iterate.</em> Implement after-action reviews immediately to account for rapid pace of change; analyze feedback and iterate appropriately. </li>
</ul>
<p>The federal government has a unique opportunity to reimagine itselfbut that window is tight. As services and operations come back online, agencies can choose to return to business as usual with some additional safeguards or to reinvent how they work and leapfrog ahead to better serve the public and the country. </p>
<hr>
<p>During the current crisis, governments have worked faster and better than they dreamed possible just a few months ago. Maintaining that sense of possibility will enable the federal government to reopen to a next normal and define a new and better future. The path forward for federal agencies is not without its challenges, but it is possible to navigate what lies ahead effectively and create positive, sustainable changes for the public and employees. </p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Megan McConnell</strong> and <strong><a href="/our-people/sarah-tucker-ray">Sarah Tucker-Ray</a></strong> are partners in McKinseys Washington, DC, office, where <strong>Asma Mirza</strong> and <strong>Meg Sachdev</strong> are consultants.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Sean Christiansen for his contribution to this article.</p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-screen-only"><div aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"COVID 19 Reopening federal normal","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"7ac86752-8bc9-45ae-8176-be2132a5a4e9","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"COVID-19: Reopening federal agency operations and reimagining a next normal"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"COVID-19: Reopening federal agency operations"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Government leaders should consider how employees can return safely to work as well as rethink their operations."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Government leaders should consider how employees can return safely to work at federal agencies as well as rethink their operations."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2020-06-05T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUS government agencies\u003c/strong\u003e are entering a period of gradual recovery following the hectic months since the first US case of COVID-19 was confirmed in January. Resuming a semblance of normal operations for 2.1 million nonpostal workers and 1.4 million active-duty military will be an undertaking that lasts many months and spans multiple stages.[[Footnote 1]] Agencies will have to carefully plan whether, how, and when to return fully to work\u0026mdash;and provide answers for each state and city in which their employees work. They will have to prioritize and sequence agency services and functions and work to create appropriate infrastructure and safeguards for employees and the citizens they serve. Federal agency leaders also face strained budgets and a substantial work backlog as well as continuing responsibility to help manage the profound humanitarian toll that COVID-19 has taken.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eThese are significant burdens by any measure, but the pandemic crisis also offers federal agencies the opportunity to reimagine an operational \u0026ldquo;next normal.\u0026rdquo; Like the private sector, agencies could question long-held assumptions and operate in previously unimaginable ways. As they plan a return, agency leaders should take stock of lessons already learned while the opportunity to effect change is greatest.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAgencies tackling the challenge of reopening should therefore consider focusing on two areas: returning employees to work and reimagining a next normal for government operations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eA blueprint for returning employees to work\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo tackle the challenge of returning employees to work, agencies can consider three main activities: segmenting agencies, assessing infrastructure, and planning the return.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSegmenting and prioritizing agency services and employees\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAgency leaders will have to make some hard choices as reopening goes forward. Two key activities will be sequencing the reopening of operations and segmenting their workforces. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAgencies can segment the reopening of operations based on criticality and risk, assessing first the urgency to reopen the service and then how effectively a service can occur without compromising employee and public health (Exhibit 1). This estimation\u0026mdash;including considering both the intrinsic public health risk of an activity, as well as its potential to be modified with safeguards\u0026mdash;will allow agencies to sequence its services into four categories:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e1. Essential low-contact services.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e Because these operations are both low risk for viral transmission and high value\u0026mdash;for instance, some national security and law enforcement activities\u0026mdash;they should be at the head of the queue for reopening. Agencies can think through the necessary actions to get these vital services up and running as quickly as possible, prioritizing those that have been most affected during the period of remote operations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e2. Essential high-contact services.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e Agencies will need to think through additional safeguards necessary to reopen and restore services quickly while minimizing the health risk to workers and the public. For example, inspections that protect the health and welfare of US residents traditionally require site visits. Actions could include steps to reduce or defer demand for these difficult-to-deliver services.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e3. Flexible low-contact services.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e In many cases, the task will be to develop processes and tools to sustain long-term remote operations. For instance, passport services may have a low urgency to reopen in-person citizen services and will have to ponder managing internal operations remotely. Agencies should consider whether any services or workers can be transitioned to remote work permanently.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e4. Deferrable high-contact services.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e The questions to consider here are whether these services can be deferred or reduced while viral transmission is active or whether the mode of service delivery can be reconfigured to reduce risk while still maintaining adequate service levels. This may include policy development, traditionally done in offices, that may move to sustained remote work.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eTo deliver these services, agencies can categorize jobs or functions by which specific roles and teams are truly essential for delivering a service, regardless of where they sit in the hierarchy. Then, agencies can map a sequence of which jobs to bring back and when to specific locations (in accordance with state and local governments\u0026rsquo; reopening laws), enabling managers to individualize work plans. In doing so, agencies can consider three workforce categories for the post-shelter-at-home environment: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eOn-site critical workers,\u003c/em\u003e whose presence on-site is essential to perform their jobs. They can be recalled in stages based on local health conditions, but a detailed plan should look at virus spread, guidance from local public health authorities, workforce readiness for return to work, and legal liability. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eOn-site flexible workers,\u003c/em\u003e many of whom might be able to complete their jobs with additional technology or simple interventions, such as being allowed to return to the office to collect documents and files. Ramp-up might be slower for these workers and include staggered shifts and flexible work arrangements as well as retraining to build more flexible skill sets.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eVirtual workers, \u003c/em\u003e who can continue to carry out their roles effectively while working from home. Remote work may also be the best choice for employees who are in specialized roles or are \u0026ldquo;single points of failure\u0026rdquo; for operational continuity\u0026mdash;that is, for whom the risk of falling ill traveling to or working in an office is simply too large for the agency\u0026rsquo;s mission. In all cases, agencies should focus on providing any additional support necessary to ensure productivity, connectivity, and health. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAcross these worker types, agencies should consider new demands and opportunities, identifying where reskilling and hiring is needed to fill new roles and responsibilities quickly.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Ceros covid]]\n\u003cp\u003eImportantly, agency employees may not be able or willing to return to work. Many workers care for young children, parents, or other loved ones affected by the pandemic. Without support, such as reopening of schools or childcare services, workers may need to continue to work remotely or not at all. Furthermore, some employees may themselves be members of vulnerable populations. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo inform their plans, agencies can start by surveying employees\u0026rsquo; readiness and comfort in returning on-site. They can also temporarily redeploy employees in lower-priority jobs or functions to higher-priority areas to fill critical gaps. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAssessing infrastructure and enacting safeguards\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMeasures to protect on-site workers will vary by workplace and type of work. Office workers, for example, will need much different methods than those required for transportation, security, or administration agents. To provide appropriate infrastructure across the agency, leaders must be able to accurately predict the working conditions for each role\u0026mdash;particularly the level of contact with members of the public or other federal workers or contractors and of control over work environment (Exhibit 2). \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eMeasures can be developed to meet the specific needs of each worker archetype and should cover three types of health-centered interventions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMeasures to ensure healthy humans, such as enforcing physical distancing and adequately sanitizing materials and products that come into contact with the broader population\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eHealthy business operations, including policies aimed at keeping workers safe, such as monitoring workers\u0026rsquo; temperatures, embracing work-from-home policies, and instituting flexible sick leave\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ePractices to limit physical contact and create a healthy work environment, such as installation of barriers between workers, adequate ventilation, no-touch bathrooms, adequate supplies of hand sanitizer, and both routine and targeted cleaning and sanitizing\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost employers have already made progress toward this planning. In a recent survey of US employers, a majority said they planned to physically separate desks or use barriers in their work environments and to close common areas and remove communal food and beverage serving equipment. Seventy-seven percent also planned to implement temperature checks for employees\u0026mdash;58 percent of whom said they planned to make this check mandatory for all employees\u0026mdash;and 55 percent planned to implement contact tracing.[[Footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis1]]\n\u003cp\u003eYet enacting adequate safeguards is not as simple as identifying and implementing the correct interventions. Agencies should examine how to get workers back to work safely while ensuring a great employee experience and a sustainable, long-term infrastructure. To tackle this challenge, agencies can focus on laying the groundwork for successful implementation and encouraging adoption among employees. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePlanning and executing the return\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePlanning a safe and effective return will require coordination across an individual agency, as well as with local, state, and other parts of the federal government. In fact, 11 of the 18 cabinet-level federal agencies have employees in all 50 states\u0026mdash;with approximately 93 percent of the total US federal workforce living outside Washington, DC. Indeed, there are federal employees and facilities in almost every county in the country.[[Footnote 3]] \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/using-a-crisis-nerve-center-to-help-reopen-the-economy\"\u003eA cross-agency governance structure\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that tackles this complexity (and other major focus areas of reopening) will be key to successfully managing this process (Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eAgencies will also have to take stock of work backlogs. Major projects will have been paused or slowed by the virus, and agencies should ascertain where to focus their resources and how to reprioritize. Agencies can conduct a rapid portfolio review and choose which activities or resources to continue, stop, defer, or ramp down\u0026mdash;and implement these decisions immediately. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEffective communication will be key to executing a safe return to an environment that encourages adoption of safeguards and is conducive to reimagination. Employees will look to their leaders for guidance, care, and empathy. In turn, leadership should consider the following guidelines when communicating:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBe visible and communicate transparently\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eKeep calm and set a tone of \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/how-to-demonstrate-calm-and-optimism-in-a-crisis\"\u003ebounded optimism\u003c/a\u003e\u0026rdquo;\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFocus on public health, emphasizing facts and reality\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBe clear about what\u0026rsquo;s expected of employees to ensure their safety\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAcknowledge emotions and uncertainty\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eKeep messages short and simple\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAnticipate and solicit questions, and provide honest responses\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the same survey of US employers mentioned above, 83 percent of employers said they have implemented new communication channels or messages to encourage safe return, and an equal share are planning to offer return-to-work trainings.[[Footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn engaging communication strategy will help agency leadership account for employees\u0026rsquo; experiences as they plan for reopening, keep employees informed as reopening plans evolve across geographies, and improve employees\u0026rsquo; comfort to return to on-site work. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eReimagining the next normal of federal agency operations \u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEven as agencies plan a safe and effective return to work, they should not wait to take advantage of the opportunities revealed by the crisis to institute the next normal. At both an organizational and individual level, the culture and environment are ripe for once-in-a-generation positive change. And done right, this change can lead to better services for citizens, better experience for government employees, and an overall accelerated step-change in how the government serves the country.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis2]]\n\u003cp\u003eThrough this crisis, organizations have realized how quickly they can move. The pace and scale of innovation has accelerated: by necessity, organizations have been forced to confront the reality of exactly what can and cannot be accomplished outside traditional processes. Going forward, employees will expect flexible hours and locations, as well as assistance to manage ever-pressing family and health needs, given gaps in elder and childcare services. And many employers are already thinking about the scale of this flexibility\u0026mdash;for example, 44 percent of US employers surveyed believe that at least a quarter of their desk-based employees would be able to work from home permanently in a new normal.[[Footnote 5]] Citizen expectations have changed as well: across demographics, there is likely to be an increased acceptance of and desire for seamless, contactless digital service. Agencies can look to the medical field for proof of change\u0026mdash;for example, 97 percent of respondents to a recent survey said they were either somewhat or very likely to use telemedicine for future appointments, even though only 8 percent of respondents had tried telehealth versus a traditional in-person visit.[[Footnote 6]] Finally, administrative demands will have shifted, with increased expectation of flexibility and cross-functional skills from the workforce, as well as to find new ways to deliver service effectively and efficiently given budget constraints.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs organizations are forced to adapt to the implications of COVID-19, many are finding faster, simpler, and less-expensive ways to operate. These practices should continue after the crisis to direct taxpayer dollars to where they can have the most impact. Organizations have been forced to pare down to essential operations; as a result, there is a unique opportunity to uncover which services are truly necessary in the next normal. Finally, the 2020 fiscal year budget is likely to be more robust than in coming years, and agencies should use this opportunity to set themselves up for leaner years by changing their operations to serve the public better and more cost-effectively.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eAt the same time, agency leaders are faced with the classic challenge of focusing on the immediate, urgent issues while finding mindshare to focus on these strategic questions. Private-sector organizations also recognize this opportunity and are rethinking everything\u0026mdash;from technology companies rethinking their real estate portfolio and planning a more decentralized approach to staffing, to financial institutions creating a \u0026ldquo;future of work task force\u0026rdquo; to devote thinking to employees\u0026rsquo; future needs\u0026mdash;all in an effort to protect against future shocks to the workforce and plan for what is needed to be successful in the next normal. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo successfully reimagine how the government operates, we have identified six approaches that agency leaders could take: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eGain support from leadership.\u003c/em\u003e First, assign a respected senior leader to sponsor \u0026ldquo;reimagination\u0026rdquo; work and clearly communicate to the workforce that it is a leadership decision and topic.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDedicate resources.\u003c/em\u003e Convene a dedicated and effective \u0026ldquo;reimagine\u0026rdquo; team to work alongside the team coordinating immediate return. The team can include representation from different agency parts or functions.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eApply customer-experience tools to rethink service delivery.\u003c/em\u003e Agencies can employ customer-experience tools such as journey mapping to uncover worker and public needs and pain points, which will have changed during the crisis. Using a resident lens, agencies can address safety and resilience and create distinctive long-term solutions while accounting for improved human experience.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eLean on data.\u003c/em\u003e Use metrics and data to inform decision making wherever possible\u0026mdash;for example, employee surveys and metrics dashboards to assess new ways of working.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eReview mission, strategy, and backlog.\u003c/em\u003e Review existing strategy and mission and adjust as needed. Continuously groom and reprioritize project backlogs as \u0026ldquo;reimagine\u0026rdquo; objectives clarify.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eReview and iterate.\u003c/em\u003e Implement after-action reviews immediately to account for rapid pace of change; analyze feedback and iterate appropriately. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe federal government has a unique opportunity to reimagine itself\u0026mdash;but that window is tight. As services and operations come back online, agencies can choose to return to business as usual with some additional safeguards or to reinvent how they work and leapfrog ahead to better serve the public and the country. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDuring the current crisis, governments have worked faster and better than they dreamed possible just a few months ago. Maintaining that sense of possibility will enable the federal government to reopen to a next normal and define a new and better future. The path forward for federal agencies is not without its challenges, but it is possible to navigate what lies ahead effectively and create positive, sustainable changes for the public and employees.
